item.title: Romania to Weigh Rate Cuts When Politics and Markets Calm
item.description: Romania will weigh further interest-rate cuts only after a return to market and political stability, the central bank chief said, as the election of a centrist candidate to the presidency on Sunday spurred preparations to form a new government.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu, Irina Vilcu

media:content.media:description: Mugur Isarescu Photographer: Andreas Arnold/Bloomberg

item.title: Musk Says He’s Pushing Ahead With OpenAI Lawsuit

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB’s Wunsch Says Economy May Need Some Support From Rates
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Pierre Wunsch said the euro-zone economy may need interest rates at “mildly supportive” levels to ensure inflation doesn’t fall below target after a series of shocks.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber, Jana Randow, Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Pierre Wunsch, governor of the National Bank of Belgium, at ECB And Its Watchers conference in Frankfurt, Germany, on Wednesday, March 22, 2023. The European Central Bank will take a "robust" approach that allows it to respond to inflation risks as needed but also aid financial markets if threats emerge, according to President Christine Lagarde. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: Canada Inflation Slows on Carbon Tax End, But Core Rises
item.description: Canadian inflation eased to its slowest pace since September on the elimination of the consumer carbon tax and lower oil prices, but core measures accelerated.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Shin, Randy Thanthong-Knight

media:content.media:description: A shopper browses a store in Toronto, Ontario. Photographer: Cole Burston/Bloomberg

item.title: White House’s Miran Dismisses Inflation Risk From Tariff Hikes
item.description: The White House’s chief economist dismissed the idea that tariff increases will have a lasting impact on US inflation, and cited the potential for interest rates to get back down to pre-Covid levels.
item.dc:creator: Skylar Woodhouse

media:content.media:description: Stephen Miran, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, speaks during the Hill & Valley forum at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, April 30, 2025. The Hill and Valley Forum, started in 2023, is a gathering of lawmakers and venture capitalists focused on the US technology industry.

item.title: Singapore Central Bank Chief Says US Dollar Assets Irreplaceable
item.description: Dollar-based assets have “enduring advantages” and remain virtually irreplaceable in the global financial system despite the US losing its top triple-A credit rating, according to Singapore’s central bank chief.
item.dc:creator: Claire Jiao

media:content.media:description: Chia Der Jiun

item.title: A Spendthrift Saudi Arabia Can’t Finance the World Anymore
item.description: Hello from Doha. I’m Erik Schatzker, editorial director of Bloomberg New Economy, bringing you a special edition of the newsletter from this year’s Qatar Economic Forum. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Erik Schatzker

item.title: India Lays Out Phased Timeline for US Trade Deal
item.description: India’s Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal is wrapping up a four-day visit to Washington on Tuesday, and he’s reporting “good discussions” with US officials on a trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

item.title: Poste Italiane Could Be Partner for Digital Euro, Cipollone Says
item.description: Poste Italiane SpA could help introduce the digital euro to Italy, according to European Central Bank Executive Board member Piero Cipollone.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio

media:content.media:description: The Euro symbol.

item.title: China Ran Record Budget Deficit With Spending Blitz Amid Tariffs
item.description: China’s fiscal stimulus pushed its four-month budget deficit to a record high, as the government ramped up support for the economy during an escalation in its trade conflict with the US.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Fran Wang

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers at the Yangshan Deepwater Port in Shanghai. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Turkey Sees ‘Huge’ Peace Dividend From End of $1.8 Trillion War
item.description: Turkey said it expects to reap “huge” economic gains from the Kurdish separatist group’s decision to stop its 40-year war in the country’s southeast.
item.dc:creator: Beril Akman, Stephanie Flanders

media:content.media:description: Mehmet Simsek Photographer: Karim Jafaar/Getty Images

item.title: BOJ Can Likely Keep Cutting Bond Buys as Market Views Diverge
item.description: The Bank of Japan likely remains on track to keep scaling back its bond buying at largely the current pace with scope to continue rolling back purchases beyond March 2026 after views of surveyed market participants diverged widely.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Japan headquarters in Tokyo. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

item.title: BOE’s Pill Warns UK Interest Rates Are Being Cut Too Quickly
item.description: Bank of England Chief Economist Huw Pill said he is concerned that UK interest rates are coming down too quickly, cementing his status as one of the most hawkish officials at the UK central bank.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Philip Aldrick, Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: The Bank of England in London.

item.title: ECB’s Knot ‘Can’t Rule Out’ Another Interest-Rate Cut in June
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Klaas Knot said another reduction in borrowing costs is possible next month, though stressed that it’s “too early” to make decisions without seeing fresh quarterly forecasts.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom

item.title: Danish Economy Contracts, Dragged Down by Lower Pharma Sales
item.description: Denmark’s economy shrank in the first quarter, dragged down by lower drug sales, underscoring the Nordic nation’s increased dependency on its large pharmaceutical sector, which is led by Novo Nordisk A/S.
item.dc:creator: Christian Wienberg, Sara Sjolin

media:content.media:description: The Novo Nordisk A/S pharmaceutical manufacturing facility in Hillerod, Denmark.

item.title: ING Sees Potential Carry-Trade Boost Ahead for EM Currencies
item.description: Emerging-market currencies are benefiting from a weaker dollar and they may get a further boost if the US cuts interest rates, attracting more capital into carry trades, according to ING Bank NV.
item.dc:creator: Peter Laca

item.title: Ghana at Loggerheads With Afreximbank Over $768 Million Debt
item.description: Ghana, emerging from a bruising debt restructuring process, faces a dispute with African Export-Import Bank, one of its biggest commercial creditors, over whether it should take losses on a $768.4 million liability.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hill, Ekow Dontoh

media:content.media:description: Cassiel Ato Forson

item.title: Uganda’s Trade Adviser Says Exports Surging Despite US Setback
item.description: Uganda’s exports have surged despite the east African nation losing its preferential access to US markets after it enacted a harsh anti-homosexuality law, according to a top presidential adviser.
item.dc:creator: Helen Nyambura, Fred Ojambo

media:content.media:description: A supervisor inspects the quality of coffee beans at the Nairobi Coffee Exchange in Nairobi. Photographer: Riccardo Gangale/Bloomberg

item.title: BOE’s Dhingra Backed Half-Point Cut to Make Statement on Economy
item.description: Bank of England rate-setter Swati Dhingra said she wanted to make a “statement” about the direction of the UK economy by breaking with other policymakers and voting for a half-point interest-rate cut at this month’s meeting.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

item.title: ECB Sees Financial Stability Risks From Escalating Global Trade Tensions
item.description: The European Central Bank warned that escalating global tariff tensions have emerged as a “significant concern” for financial stability and the global economy.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: The Behala inland port in Berlin.

item.title: Australia Delivers ‘Dovish’ Rate Cut, Sends Yields Tumbling
item.description: Australia’s central bank cut its key interest rate for a second time this year, highlighting mounting trade-related uncertainty and sending the currency and government bond yields tumbling.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Britain’s EU Reset Turns Out to Be Just the Start of Talks
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer heralded a “landmark deal” between the UK and the European Union on Monday that he billed as a reset moment for relations under his government. Still, with many details unresolved, Brexit never quite seems to be over.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Alberto Nardelli, Jorge Valero, Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Antonio Costa, president of the European Council, Keir Starmer, UK prime minister, and Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, left to right, during a news conference at the UK-EU summit at Lancaster House in London, UK, on Monday, May 19, 2025. Negotiators for the European Union and the UK have reached a deal to strengthen their post-Brexit relationship ahead of a summit on Monday, according to people familiar with the discussions and documents seen by Bloomberg. Photographer: Neil Hall/EPA

item.title: Malaysia Trade Jumps to Near Three-Year High Amid Front-Loading
item.description: Malaysia’s trade rose to an almost three-year high, with exports surpassing expectations amid front-loading activity.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry

media:content.media:description: Photo: Richard Humphries/Bloomberg Photographer: Richard Humphries/Bloomberg

item.title: Sanctioned Russian Arctic LNG Plant Is Using New Production Line
item.description: Russia’s newest liquefied natural gas plant in the Arctic has begun using a second production line, even as the facility remains under stifling Western restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Anna Shiryaevskaya, Stephen Stapczynski

media:content.media:description: Natalia KOLESNIKOVA / AFP/Getty Images Photographer: NATALIA KOLESNIKOVA/AFP

item.title: RBA Sees Unemployment Rise to Near 6% in a ‘Trade War’ Scenario
item.description: Australia’s central bank warned that the unemployment rate would climb to nearly 6% in a “trade war” scenario where the US re-imposes higher ‘Liberation Day’ tariffs in 2026 and all countries retaliate.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Japan Mulls Taxing Small Parcels as Shein, Temu Expand
item.description: Japan is mulling a review of tax exemptions for small parcels including those shipped from China, joining a slew of governments stepping up scrutiny over a duty-free channel used by Shein and PDD Holdings Inc’s Temu.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

item.title: Nigeria to Hold Rates Again on Hazy Inflation Outlook
item.description: Policymakers at Nigeria’s central bank are set to keep the key interest rate on hold for a second straight meeting to get a better grasp of the inflation trajectory.
item.dc:creator: Nduka Orjinmo

media:content.media:description: Olayemi Cardoso

item.title: China Accuses US of Undermining Trade Talks With Warnings Against Huawei Chips
item.description: The Chinese government accused the Trump administration of undermining recent trade talks in Geneva after it warned that using Huawei Technologies Co.’s artificial-intelligence chips “anywhere in the world” would violate US export controls.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Tam, Debby Wu

media:content.media:description: A corporate logo sits on a Huawei Technologies Co. NetEngine 8000 intelligent metro router on display during a 5G event in London, U.K., on Thursday, Feb. 20, 2020. Huawei said at the event it currently has 91 contracts for 5G, with 47 of those in Europe.

item.title: Thailand Eyes $15 Billion Cut in US Trade Gap With Export Rules
item.description: Thailand expects to reduce its trade gap with the US by as much as $15 billion annually with its recent initiatives to prevent the misuse of origin rules for exports, according to Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

item.title: India Expects Multi-Phase Trade Deal With US as Talks Proceed
item.description: India is discussing a US trade deal structured in three tranches and expects to reach an interim agreement before July, when President Donald Trump’s reciprocal tariffs are set to kick in, according to officials in New Delhi familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava, Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump, right, and Narendra Modi in February.
